etymologies: late Middle English: from French ingénieux or Latin ingeniosus, from ingenium ‘mind, intellect’; compare with engine

notes.text: Ingenious and ingenuous are often confused. Ingenious means ‘clever, skillful, resourceful’ (an ingenious device), while ingenuous means ‘artless, frank’ (charmed by the ingenuous honesty of the child)

definitions: (of a person) clever, original, and inventive

examples.text: he was ingenious enough to overcome the limited budget

definitions: (of a machine or idea) cleverly and originally devised and well suited to its purpose

examples.text: his theory, while ingenious, is most assuredly incorrect

shortDefinitions: cleverly and originally devised and well suited to its purpose
